section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Alphabet Knowledge; Phonological Awareness

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Ww and Yy, engage children with dancing, and introduce a new vocabulary word (together).
Begin Story Time by introducing the Big Book and asking, In what ways do the animals have fun?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Blend phonemes in one-syllable words.
Make connections between situations.
Follow oral directions.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.

small-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Drawing paper, crayons, yellow paper circles

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to wiggle their fingers if a word begins like wiggle and hold up a yellow circle if a word begins like yellow.
Invite children to draw a wiggly worm and a yellow yo-yo.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What characters are in your book? How do they move?
What storybook animal will you pretend to be? How will you move while you are pretending?
How can you sort these objects? What groups will you have?
What are you writing about?
How can you use these things to make music?
Which letter is uppercase W? Which letter is lowercase w? Which letter is uppercase Y? Which letter is lowercase y?
What are you building? What materials will you use?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder make connections, and introduce a related vocabulary word (connection).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Everybunny Dance!
Read closely and notice when the characters make connections.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Blend phonemes in one-syllable words.
Make connections between situations.
Follow oral directions.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to name different ways to move.
Help children develop executive function and gross motor skills by taking steps to do three new actions in sequence.
Differentiate and modify as needed

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do the characters in this story do for fun?
Make up a dance. Show different ways to move.
What parts of your body do you use when you dance?
Make up a silly song that is about bunnies.
Make a musical instrument. What materials will you use?
Show me the letter that begins bunny. Show me the letter that begins fox.
Can you make a place the bunnies can hide when they see the fox?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall. Copyright © 2017 Ellie Sandall. section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Phonological Awareness; Writing

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and engage children in a chant.
Start Story Time by revisiting Everybunny Dance! and asking the guiding question, What are some ways the animals dance?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Blend phonemes in one-syllable words.
Make plans and take steps towards a goal.
Follow oral directions.
Distinguish words that sound similar but have different meanings.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Show interest and appreciation for others’ work.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children learn to blend phonemes to say one-syllable words with pictorial support: fox, dog, and cat. Write the first letter of each animal name.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the character in your book like the characters in the story we read today?
Why do you move differently to different kinds of music? Materials: scarves, fans to experiment with dance/movement, recorded music.
Why do these instruments have different sounds?
Think of some words that describe dancing. Can you write about dancing?
How can you make a picture that shows children moving?
Find a letter b. Why do you need a letter b to spell bunny? Find a letter f. Why do you need a letter f to spell fox?
Can you build a drum? What materials will you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall. Copyright © 2017 Ellie Sandall. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Old MacDonald’s Farm

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Phonological Awareness; Writing

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about farm animals, play a rhyming game and introduce the vocabulary word (farm).
Start Story Time by connecting the texts, Everybunny Dance! and Old MacDonald’s Farm.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question, How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Identify rhyming words.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence.
Make connections between situations.
Follow oral directions.
Distinguish words that sound similar but have different meanings.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Old MacDonald’s Farm

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify pairs of rhyming words.
Share rhyming word pairs with children and have them use them to play a matching game.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which do you like better, stories or songs? Why?
What is your favorite kind farm animal? Why?
Compare these toy animals. How can you sort them?
What animal would you like to write a song about?
Make a baby farm animal and its mom. Which one of them should be bigger?
Think of a farm animal. What sound does it begin with?
What blocks can you use to build Old MacDonald’s Farm?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall. Copyright © 2017 Ellie Sandall. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out and describe favorite pretend play and introduce vocabulary (cheer).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Everybunny Dance! and asking, What are some ways we sing, dance, and play like the bunnies?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence.
Make connections between situations.
Follow oral directions.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What is your favorite way to express yourself through music and dance?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s responses to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is your favorite book in the library now? Why?
Imagine you are a bunny or a fox. What will you do?
Can you use pattern blocks to make an animal?
Would you like to play the drums or blow a horn? Write about the one you like.
Which part of your work today do you like best?
Can you make up names for some of the bunnies? How will you spell them?
Which blocks would be most helpful to use to build a house for a bunny?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall. Copyright © 2017 Ellie Sandall. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Recognizes and blends spoken phonemes into one syllable words with pictorial support.
Make connections between situations.
Respond to different musical styles through movement and play.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Recognizes and blends spoken phonemes into one syllable words with pictorial support.
Make connections between situations.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Phonological Awareness: Recognizes and blends spoken phonemes into one syllable words with pictorial support. (TX.III.B.9):

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Perceive differences between similar-sounding words.
Demonstrate interest in and show appreciation for the creative work of others.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Can recognize rhyming words.
Move from scribbles to some letter-sound correspondence using beginning and ending sounds when writing.
Make connections between situations.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Perceive differences between similar-sounding words.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Move from scribbles to some letter-sound correspondence using beginning and ending sounds when writing.
Make connections between situations.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
